**M.G.L. c. 212, \u00a7 3**.proposition: Pursuant to **M.G.L. c. 212, § 3**, the Superior Court Department of the Trial Court of the Commonwealth of Massachusetts has jurisdiction over this matter because the amount in controversy exceeds $50,000.

**M.G.L. c. 223, \u00a7 1**.proposition: Venue is proper in this Court under **M.G.L. c. 223, § 1** because the defendant resides or the tort occurred in Suffolk County.

**Massaletti v. Fitzroy**, 228 Mass. 487.proposition: Under Massachusetts law, all motorists owe a duty to exercise reasonable care to avoid causing foreseeable harm to others using the roadways, including bicyclists.
**Massaletti v. Fitzroy**, 228 Mass. 487.support_reasoning: The opinion is about the standard of care owed by a host giving a gratuitous automobile ride to a guest, and whether liability requires proof of gross negligence rather than ordinary negligence. It does not address the general duty of motorists using public roadways toward other roadway users such as bicyclists, nor does it discuss foreseeable harm to others on the road. The case concerns a host–guest relationship in a private automobile and the doctrine of gratuitous undertakings, not the general duty of reasonable care owed by all motorists to others using the highways.
**Massaletti v. Fitzroy**, 228 Mass. 487.relevant_excerpt: "It was decided in West v. Poor, 196 Mass. 183, that a defendant who invites a plaintiff to ride gratis in his carriage is liable to the same extent that a gratuitous bailee is liable... As matter of authority West v. Poor, 196 Mass. 183, ought not to be overruled... The measure of liability of one who undertakes to carry gratis is the same as that of one who undertakes to keep gratis."

**Glidden v. Maglio,** 430 Mass. 694, 69.proposition: Under Massachusetts law, all motorists owe a duty to exercise reasonable care to avoid causing foreseeable harm to others using the roadways, including bicyclists.
**Glidden v. Maglio,** 430 Mass. 694, 69.support_reasoning: The opinion in Glidden v. Maglio concerns a premises/construction-site negligence claim against a property owner/general contractor, focusing on causation and statutory building code issues. It does not involve a motor vehicle, roadway use, or the duties of motorists toward bicyclists or other road users. Because the court neither states nor analyzes any rule about motorists’ duties to exercise reasonable care toward bicyclists, this case does not support the claimed proposition.
**Glidden v. Maglio,** 430 Mass. 694, 69.relevant_excerpt: With respect to each such claim, the plaintiffs bear the burden of proving that the defendant committed a breach of the duty to use reasonable care, that the plaintiffs suffered actual loss, and that the defendant’s negligence caused their loss. See Restatement (Second) of Torts § 281 (1965); J.R. Nolan & L.J. Sartorio, Tort Law § 204 (2d ed. 1989). Causation is an essential element of that proof.

**M.G.L. c. 90, \u00a7 14**.proposition: Defendant owed Plaintiff a duty to exercise reasonable care in the operation and use of his motor vehicle, including the duty to ensure it was safe before opening his vehicle door into a lane of travel.

**Carter v. Towne**, 98 Mass. App. Ct. 4.proposition: Defendant breached his duty of care by opening his car door into the bicycle lane without verifying that the adjacent lane was clear of oncoming bicyclists, in violation of **M.G.L. c. 90, § 14** and the standards articulated in **Carter v. Towne**, 98 Mass. App. Ct. 458 (2020).

**Uloth v. City Tank Corp.**, 376 Mass..proposition: Defendant’s conduct constituted negligence as defined in **Uloth v. City Tank Corp.**, 376 Mass. 874, 879 (1978) (reasonable person standard of care).
**Uloth v. City Tank Corp.**, 376 Mass..support_reasoning: The cited portion of Uloth discusses the standard for negligent *design* of products (duty to design with reasonable care, considering safer alternative designs), not the general negligence definition or a generic reasonable person standard of care. It addresses what a reasonable *designer/manufacturer* must do regarding product safety, rather than articulating a broad, generally applicable reasonable person negligence standard. Thus, using this case for a generic negligence definition is inaccurate or at least incomplete.
**Uloth v. City Tank Corp.**, 376 Mass..relevant_excerpt: "We do not read Schaeffer as establishing a rule that a product which functions as intended may not be negligently designed. A designer has a duty 'to design the machine with reasonable care.' doCanto v. Ametek, Inc., 367 Mass. 776, 782 (1975). … In our view the focus in design negligence cases is not on how the product is meant to function, but on whether the product is designed with reasonable care to eliminate avoidable dangers."

**Lynn v. Lynn**, 302 Mass. 565, 566 (19.proposition: Defendant’s failure to keep a proper lookout and to refrain from distracted behavior—such as engaging with his cellphone—further falls below the standard of care required of a reasonably prudent driver.
**Lynn v. Lynn**, 302 Mass. 565, 566 (19.support_reasoning: The case is a workers’ compensation decision about permanent partial disability, earning capacity, and the validity of a lump-sum award to a minor. It does not involve an automobile accident, driving conduct, lookout duties, or distracted driving (such as cellphone use), nor does it discuss the standard of care for drivers. Accordingly, it provides no authority for the proposition about a driver’s failure to keep a proper lookout or avoid distraction falling below the standard of care.
**Lynn v. Lynn**, 302 Mass. 565, 566 (19.relevant_excerpt: The employee testified that he had difficulty in driving an automobile in the daytime as there was a glare in his right eye and he would have to keep the left eye closed; and that he could not operate an automobile at night. The single member observed the employee’s eyes and stated for the record “that it is very apparent that he has an injury to the left eye.” The nature and extent of the injury, the appearance of the eye, and the testimony of the insurer’s specialist warranted a finding that the employee has a permanently disabling injury.

**Gorey v. Guarente**, 303 Mass. 569, 57.proposition: Defendant’s failure to keep a proper lookout and to refrain from distracted behavior—such as engaging with his cellphone—further falls below the standard of care required of a reasonably prudent driver.
**Gorey v. Guarente**, 303 Mass. 569, 57.support_reasoning: The opinion concerns construction of a trust instrument and a will, and issues of probate procedure on appeal. It does not involve motor vehicle operation, negligence, standards of care for drivers, lookout obligations, or cellphone/distracted driving. Accordingly, it cannot be cited as authority for the proposition about a driver’s duty to keep a proper lookout and avoid distraction.

**Craig v. Everett M. Brooks Co.**, 351.raw_text: **Craig v. Everett M. Brooks Co.**, 351 Mass. 497, 501 (1967)
**Craig v. Everett M. Brooks Co.**, 351.proposition: Plaintiff’s resulting injuries were a direct and proximate result of Defendant’s negligence.
**Craig v. Everett M. Brooks Co.**, 351.case_name: Craig v. Everett M. Brooks Co.
**Craig v. Everett M. Brooks Co.**, 351.support_reasoning: The case concerns whether a civil engineer can be liable in negligence to a contractor not in privity for pecuniary loss caused by negligently placed stakes. It does not involve personal injuries or analyze whether any injuries were a direct and proximate result of the defendant’s negligence; the harm discussed is purely economic (rebuilding work, extra cost). Thus, it does not support a proposition about plaintiff’s resulting injuries being the direct and proximate result of defendant’s negligence.
**Craig v. Everett M. Brooks Co.**, 351.relevant_excerpt: “The question remains whether the law permits recovery for pecuniary loss due to erroneous placing of stakes. … In the case at bar … where the identity of the only possible plaintiff and the extent of his reliance were known to the defendant, and where damages are not remote, it is reasonable to reach an analogous result. … Accordingly, we hold that it was error to direct a verdict for the defendant on count 2.”

**Jupin v. Kask**, 447 Mass. 141, 146 (2.proposition: The type and manner of harm suffered by Plaintiff were foreseeable consequences of Defendant’s actions.
**Jupin v. Kask**, 447 Mass. 141, 146 (2.support_reasoning: The opinion expressly analyzes foreseeability in the context of negligence and holds that the theft of the handgun and its use to shoot a police officer were foreseeable consequences of the defendant’s failure to ensure proper storage of firearms on her property. The court emphasizes that it is enough that the same general kind of harm (violent criminal misuse of a stolen gun) was foreseeable, even if the precise manner (shooting a police officer during a foot chase) was not, which aligns directly with the claimed proposition about type and manner of harm being foreseeable consequences of the defendant’s actions.
**Jupin v. Kask**, 447 Mass. 141, 146 (2.relevant_excerpt: “As in Pine Manor, the risk in the instant case — that a mentally unstable and violent person, to whom unfettered and unsupervised access to Kask’s home was granted, would take a gun from that home and shoot someone — was both foreseeable and foreseen. … It is irrelevant whether Kask foresaw or should have foreseen the specific danger that occurred — i.e., that Jason would shoot a police officer during a foot chase. … It is sufficient that the same general kind of harm was a foreseeable consequence of the defendant’s risk-creating conduct.”

**Poskus v. Lombardo\u2019s of Randolph,.raw_text: **Poskus v. Lombardo’s of Randolph, Inc.**, 423 Mass. 637, 639 (1996)
**Poskus v. Lombardo\u2019s of Randolph,.proposition: Defendant’s negligence was the sole and proximate cause of Plaintiff’s bodily injuries, emotional distress, lost wages, and property damage.
**Poskus v. Lombardo\u2019s of Randolph,.case_name: Poskus v. Lombardo's of Randolph, Inc.
**Poskus v. Lombardo\u2019s of Randolph,.support_reasoning: The quoted concurrence states that the facts would not warrant a jury in finding the plaintiff’s injuries were within the reasonably foreseeable risk created by the defendant’s negligence. That is the opposite of finding that defendant’s negligence was the sole and proximate cause of the plaintiff’s injuries. The case therefore rejects, rather than supports, the proposition that Lombardo’s negligence was the proximate cause of the plaintiff’s damages.
**Poskus v. Lombardo\u2019s of Randolph,.relevant_excerpt: “I concur in the view that ‘[t]he facts would not warrant a jury’s finding that the plaintiffs injuries were within the reasonably foreseeable risk of harm created by Lombardo’s negligence.’ Ante at 640-641.”

**M.G.L. c. 231, \u00a7 85**.proposition: Plaintiff is entitled to compensatory damages under **M.G.L. c. 231, § 85**, as well as all other applicable Massachusetts common and statutory law remedies.

**M.G.L. c. 231, \u00a7 6B**.proposition: Costs and reasonable interest pursuant to **M.G.L. c. 231, § 6B**;
